question: What are the reasons for termination in Germany?
context:
Termination
If you wish to resign as an employee, you must send your notice in writing, preferably by post, to your employer.
If you have been dismissed by your employer and want to do something about it, you only have 3 weeks to do so.
You must file a claim with the help of a lawyer or/and with the Legal Claims Office at the labor court.
The notice period for employers is normally 4 weeks to the end of a month.
The deadline for employees depends on the duration of the employment relationship.

question: Where can I find medical help for children?
context:
What should I do if my child is ill?
If your child is ill or cannot go to school for other important reasons, you must report it to the school.
Please call the school before the start of lessons.
Most schools also expect a written apology.
This is a letter from the parents.
The written excuse must often be received by the school within three days.
If your child is ill for a longer period of time, they will need a doctor's note.
The certificate must also be handed in at school.
It is best to ask the secretary what the school needs.
If your child does not come to school without a telephone or written excuse or a medical certificate, the school must look for your child.
If necessary, the school will even search for your child with the police.
You may then have to pay a fine.

question: What are the requirements for funding from the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF)?
context:
Social justice
The state must respect and protect human dignity.
It should therefore ensure the best possible social justice.
To this end, it takes legal, financial and material measures.
All people in Germany who earn money pay part of their wages to the state.
The higher the income, the more you have to pay.
If you earn a lot, you pay more tax.
The state should spend this money on the welfare of people living in Germany.
This means, for example:
All people registered in Germany are entitled to basic medical care.
This includes medical treatment in the event of illness and accidents.
All people who have a job subject to social insurance contributions pay contributions to health insurance, long-term care insurance and pension insurance.
Every adult must make an effort to earn their own living.
If someone is unable to do this, help can be obtained from the state.
The state ensures that taxes are also used to balance social justice and to help in emergency situations (for example for refugees).
The state supports parents financially, for example through child benefit.
This is not permitted in Germany, for example:
Tax fraud, for example paying less tax than required.
Receiving state benefits even though there is no entitlement to them.

question: What is meant by "primary care"?
context:
General practitioner, pediatrician and specialist
General practitioner
In Germany, there are doctors in every city who work in a practice and not in a clinic - these are called GPs.
Anyone with health concerns or questions should first go to a family doctor.
To avoid having to wait too long, it is important to make an appointment in advance.
You can choose your own family doctor.
As a rule, you don't change your family doctor.
There are GPs in almost every town.
They set their own opening hours.
GPs carry out important examinations and are your first point of contact in the event of illness.
Consult your family doctor if you
are acutely ill (e.g. flu or cold)
are chronically ill (e.g. diabetes or rheumatism)
Have pain
want to be vaccinated
are pregnant
General practitioners decide on necessary medication and whether a specialist examination is required.
Your GP can also give you sick leave if you are unable to work.
If necessary, your GP will refer you to a specialist who can carry out special examinations.
Here you can search for a family doctor or a specialist in your area.
Here you will also find the foreign-language health services available in the Rems-Murr district.
If you cannot find a doctor who speaks your language, you will need to find an interpreter.
Sometimes the costs of professional interpreters can be covered.
Pediatrician
Children are usually examined by pediatricians.
Regular check-ups and vaccinations at the pediatrician are important for the health of every child.
The prescribed preventive examinations are called "U examinations" and are always free of charge at a specific time.
When registering at a day care center, proof of complete screening examinations may be requested.
If your child is ill and cannot go to school, the pediatrician can issue a medical certificate.
Important!
Your child must be vaccinated against measles when attending a day care center or school.
Specialist
If you need a specialist doctor, your family doctor will refer you to a specialist.
They can carry out special examinations.
Women's health
It is important that women are regularly examined by a gynecologist.
In this way, diseases can be detected in good time.
These are called preventive medical check-ups.
You can also discuss the topic of contraception there.
Further information on this topic:
Video │ Good to know - Visit to the gynecologist │ Media center of the GWA St.

Men's health
Urologists are responsible, among other things, for diseases of the male reproductive organs and for preventive medical check-ups.
You can find more information about men's health here.
Dental health
If you have a toothache, go to a dentist.
Regular check-ups at the dentist are important for your dental health.
You can find more information on dental health here.

question: What is the difference between a home birth and a hospital birth?
context:
Important information about pregnancy
First appointment with the gynecologist
Pregnant women in Germany enjoy special protection and are entitled to advice, medical care and support with new purchases for the child.
If you are pregnant, you must first go to your gynecologist.
Have the preventive check-ups carried out there.
You will then receive a maternity pass.
The maternity record is a document containing important information about your pregnancy, your health and that of your child.
Always take your maternity pass with you in case of emergencies.
Maternity protection for working pregnant women
Working pregnant women have special protection - known as maternity protection.
Maternity protection begins 6 weeks before the birth and ends 8 weeks after.
This protection is regulated by law in Germany.
Pregnant women are generally not allowed to work during this time.
Your job is retained and you can return to work at the end of your maternity leave.
In addition, pregnant women may not work more than 8.5 hours per day and may not perform heavy physical labor.
Midwife
Midwives support women and their families from the beginning of pregnancy to the end of breastfeeding.
Midwives provide advice during pregnancy, can help with the birth, introduce breastfeeding after the birth and also take care of the woman's physical and psychological recovery.
Every woman can call on the help of a midwife.
Most services are covered by health insurance.
Website Midwives Association in German and English
You can find a midwife in the Rems-Murr district here
Pregnancy counseling
Women and men can go there for free and anonymous advice on all questions, issues and changes relating to pregnancy and family planning.
Regardless of whether they need medical or legal information, for example.
The counseling service is also available for mothers and young families after the birth of a child.
Women and men with an unfulfilled desire to have children can also seek advice.
Counseling centers Rems-Murr-Kreis:
Rem-Murr district administration office
schwanger@rems-murr-kreis.de
pro familia Waiblingen
waiblingen@profamilia.de
Financial support
If you have little or no income, you can apply for unemployment benefit II or assistance under the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act (AsylbLG).
After the twelfth week of pregnancy, the Jobcenter or social welfare office will pay expectant mothers additional needs and initial equipment for pregnancy and baby.
Child benefit
As a rule, all children in Germany are entitled to a child allowance from birth until they reach the age of 18.
You are entitled to child benefit from the age of 18.
In individual cases, the entitlement may last longer.
Parental allowance
Many parents want to look after their child after the birth.
In return, they do not work for a certain period of time.
Or they only work part-time.
Parental allowance is paid during this time.

question: When are the normal conditions for family reunification not applied?
context:
Family reunification
Family reunification
People who already have a residence permit and live permanently in Germany have the option of bringing spouses living abroad, partners in a registered civil partnership and their own underage children to join them.
The regulations and requirements that apply depend on which group of people you belong to:
Nationals of an EU Member State
Nationals of the European Economic Area (EEA states Iceland, Norway and Liechtenstein), Swiss nationals
Nationals of the following countries: Australia, Canada, Israel, Japan, United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, New Zealand, United States of America, Republic of Korea, Brazil, El Salvador
Third-country nationals
Persons who have applied for asylum in Germany and have been granted protection status:
Recognition as a person entitled to asylum pursuant to Art.
16a Basic Law (GG) (legal entitlement, attention: time limit, see below!)
Recognition of refugee status in accordance with the Geneva Refugee Convention pursuant to § 3 of the Asylum Act (AsylG) (legal entitlement, please note: deadline regulation, see below!)
Granting of subsidiary protection according to § 4 Asylum Act (AsyG) (legal entitlement, attention: deadline regulation, see below!)
Family reunification is excluded for people with a tolerated stay permit.
In principle, the following applies:
Both spouses must be at least 18 years old
the marriage or registered civil partnership must have already existed in the country of origin
All other requirements vary depending on the group of people.
We therefore recommend that you seek advice from a migration advice center (MBE) or the foreigners authority.
Deadline regulation
Important note: For persons who have been granted protection status in an asylum procedure (see list above), a deadline regulation applies: The normally applicable requirements, such as a secure livelihood and sufficient living space, are waived if the application for family reunification was submitted to the competent authorities (foreign mission in the country of residence of your family members and the Foreigners' Registration Office in Munich) within three months of incontestable recognition.
Further information on family reunification for persons with protection status can be found on the website of the
Foreign Office (German, English, Arabic) and the Munich city administration:

2 sentence 1, alternative 1 AufenthG and travel document

2 sentence 1, alternative 2 AufenthG

question: Where can I find cheap cell phone rates?
context:
Smartphone
There are two different cell phone contracts in Germany: Prepaid contract and fixed-term contract.
The prepaid contract has no fixed contract term.
This means that you pay a certain amount for a certain period of time (often four weeks).
You do not have to cancel the prepaid contract if you no longer want to use it.
A fixed-term contract has a minimum contract term.
This means that you have to stay with a particular provider for a longer period of time.
The contract is automatically extended if you do not cancel.
If you do not want the contract to be extended automatically, you must cancel in writing.
Pay attention to the notice period.
Ten important questions for concluding a contract:
How high is the basic fee?
Does the fee increase after a certain time?
Is there a minimum monthly turnover (minimum costs per month)?
How long does the contract last (e.g.
B.twelve or 24 months)?
If I don't cancel the contract, it will be automatically renewed.
When do I have to cancel if I don't want to extend the contract?
How much does it cost to set up, switch and deactivate?
Which time cycle (60/1, 10/10) is used for the calculation?
How much does a minute cost (external/own network)?
How much does a cell phone with a contract cost and how much does a cell phone without a contract cost?
How much does the Internet cost?
How much do international calls cost?
You can find important information in five different languages (German, English, Arabic, Russian, Farsi) at the consumer advice center: www.verbraucherzentrale.de (search term: "multilingual information").
There you will also find explanatory videos on the topic in German, English, Arabic and Dari.

question: What documents are required for the asylum appeal procedure?
context:
Legal action
Legal action
You do not agree with the negative decision on your asylum application by the BAMF?
Then you can sue.
You are the "plaintiff" or the "claimant".
The BAMF is the "defendant".
In the event of an appeal, the Munich Administrative Court will review the BAMF's decision.
If it agrees with the BAMF, the case will be dismissed.
The obligation to leave the country remains in force.
If the administrative court does not agree with the BAMF, you will receive a residence permit.
The BAMF is then obliged to grant you protection.
You can also take legal action against a positive decision by the BAMF.
For example, if you do not agree with the form of protection granted (exception: recognition of refugee status).
You should always seek advice and representation from a specialist lawyer for asylum and residence law.

Net cold rent = basic rent without operating costs
plus

question: How can a newcomer register to vote?
context:
Right to vote
People in Germany have the right to vote.
They are allowed to vote for politicians.
That is written in a law.
And these are the most important elections in Germany:
Landtag election
You elect politicians for the Landtag in your federal state.
The Landtag decides things for the federal state.
A new Landtag is always elected after 5 years.
Election to the Bundestag
You elect politicians for the Bundestag.
The Bundestag decides things for the whole of Germany.
A new Bundestag is always elected after 4 years.
European election
You elect politicians for the European Parliament.
The European Parliament decides things for all countries in the European Union.
A new European Parliament is always elected after 5 years.
In Germany there are 2 different electoral rights:
1. the active right to vote
You have a German passport.
And you are 18 years or older.
Then you have the active right to vote.
This means that you can vote.
For example, in these elections:
Bundestag election
Landtag election
Local elections
Mayor election
Senior citizens' council election
2. the right to stand for election
You have a German passport.
And you are 18 years or older.
Then you have the right to stand for election.
This means: You can be elected by other people.
You can then work as a politician.
For example, you then work
For the German Bundestag
For the Landtag
For local government
For the Foreigners' Advisory Council
You are an EU citizen.
You may then vote in Germany in these elections:

question: At what age can children be vaccinated against TBE?
context:
Further STIKO vaccination recommendations
1. tBE (tick-borne encephalitis)
TBE is transmitted via tick bites.
Possible consequences of the disease are inflammation of the brain, the meninges and the spinal cord.
Bavaria, Baden-Württemberg and southern parts of Hesse, Thuringia and Saxony in particular are considered risk areas in Germany.
Vaccination against TBE is recommended by the STIKO in these areas in particular.
All children can be vaccinated against TBE from their 1st birthday.
2. flu (influenza)
Influenza is as contagious as a normal cold (flu-like infection).
Transmission in kindergartens and schools usually occurs from child to child.
Or about objects.
Children with pre-existing conditions are particularly affected.
They can lead to complications such as pneumonia.
The recommendation for an annual flu vaccination is therefore only aimed at children with a higher risk of complications.
You can find further information on the pre-existing conditions concerned here.
3. HPV (human papillomavirus)
Papillomaviruses can cause cancer in the long term.
Vaccination can therefore reduce the risk of cancer of the cervix, anus, penis and throat.
Vaccination before the first sexual contact offers the best protection.
Both vaccinations are recommended between the ages of 9 and 14.
4. meningococci
Meningococci are bacteria that can cause bacterial meningitis or blood poisoning (sepsis).
Children under the age of 5 and adolescents in particular are among the risk groups.
Vaccination against meningococcal type C is recommended at the age of 12 months.
There is currently no general recommendation for vaccinations against other types (B and ACWY).
The bacteria are transmitted via the so-called
Droplet infection.
This means, for example, coughing, sneezing or kissing.
5. pneumococci
Pneumococcus is the most common pathogen causing serious bacterial infections.
They can cause meningitis, pneumonia or middle ear infections.
They are particularly dangerous for babies and small children.
Three vaccinations against pneumococci are recommended.
These should be administered at the same time as the vaccination against tetanus, diphtheria and whooping cough.
6. rotaviruses
Rotaviruses are the most common cause of diarrhea and vomiting in children.
The pathogen is very contagious.
This is why almost all children contract the disease in the first five years - usually at the age of 2.
In infants in particular, a large loss of fluids and salt can lead to dangerous dehydration.
This may have to be
be treated in hospital.
Vaccination against rotaviruses is given two or three times, depending on the vaccine.
The first vaccination should be given between 6 weeks and 2 months of age.
The second vaccination at 3 months.
And the third, if necessary, at 4 months.
Vaccination against the coronavirus is currently only recommended for children aged 5 to 11 years with the "Comirnaty" vaccine from BioNTech/Pfizer.
Vaccinations can be given three to six weeks apart between the first and second vaccination.
The vaccination recommendation is primarily aimed at children who have an increased risk of a severe course due to a previous illness.
In addition, the recommendation also applies to children who are surrounded by people with a high risk of severe COVID-19 if they cannot be vaccinated themselves or the vaccination protection is not sufficient.
There is currently no recommendation for children without pre-existing illnesses or pre-existing illnesses of close contacts.
Nevertheless, it is possible to have your child vaccinated after consulting a doctor.
Further information on the pre-existing conditions concerned can be found at:
https://www.zusammengegencorona.de/impfen/kinder/corona-schutzimpfung-ab-5-jahren/
Further information on the vaccination recommendations mentioned here.

question: Which is the capital of the federal state of Bavaria?
context:
Interesting facts about the city
Interesting facts about the city
Munich is the capital of the federal state of Bavaria, which is officially called the "Free State of Bavaria".
With 1.56 million inhabitants, Munich is the third largest city in Germany.
Munich enjoys a worldwide reputation as a center of art, culture and science.
The city offers a lively nightlife and a very good public transport network.
The people of Munich particularly love their numerous green oases, such as the English Garden, the Isar floodplains and the parks of the castles, as well as the proximity to the Alps and the Upper Bavarian lakes.
Munich is economically very successful: a low unemployment rate and a broad spectrum of economic sectors make Munich attractive for many people who find exciting jobs in companies and research institutions or come to study at one of the renowned universities.
The name comes from "apud Munichen" - by the monks - because a Benedictine monastery first stood here.
The most famous member of the Bavarian royal family is undoubtedly fairytale King Ludwig II, who was born in Nymphenburg Palace, the summer residence of the Wittelsbach family in Munich.
Munich has numerous museums.
One of the oldest and best known is the
German Museum, which shows the history and future of technology.
The
BMW Welt and the BMW Museum attract visitors from all over the world.
Munich's history during the Nazi dictatorship is illuminated by the
NS Documentation Center as a central place of learning and remembrance.
In addition to the city's rich culture, the people of Munich love their sport.
Special occasions are often commemorated with a special lighting concept: for example, the arena is illuminated in the blue and yellow of the European flag on Europe Day, and on the Irish national holiday St.
Patrick's Day in bright green and to celebrate Christopher Street Day in the colors of the rainbow.
The Munich Oktoberfest - the largest folk festival in the world - is known worldwide and is visited by six million people every year.
Munich's famous beer can be enjoyed just as well, but more quietly, under chestnut trees in one of the many beer gardens.
These have a tradition of over 200 years in Munich and are considered the epitome of the Bavarian way of life.

context:
Measles Protection Act
All children must be vaccinated or immune against measles.
The parents must provide proof.
This obligation also applies to children who are cared for in a children's home for at least four weeks.
And also for children in refugee accommodation.
Measles is one of the most contagious infectious diseases.
This is why almost all people without vaccination protection become infected with the virus after just one contact with a sick person.
Measles can lead to serious complications, particularly in children under five and adults over 20.
Inflammation of the middle ear or lungs and diarrhea are among the most common symptoms.
When are vaccinations given?
1st vaccination: Between the age of 11 and the age of 18.
and 14.
Month of life (after the 9th month at the earliest)
2nd vaccination: before the 2nd birthday at the latest
The minimum interval between the two vaccinations is four weeks.
The measles vaccination is given in combination with a vaccination against mumps, rubella and possibly
Chickenpox.

context:

Benefits from the Job Centre
Who for: Households that receive financial support from the Jobcentre.
Rent and heating
Costs are covered if they are reasonable (§22 SGB II).
In the case of the City of Munich, fixed
rent ceilings apply.
For households with seven or more persons, the rent ceiling includes 15 m² and 270 Euros per additional person.
The amounts for the rent ceiling refer to the gross cold rent.
A gross cold rent is made up as follows:
Net cold rent = basic rent without operating costs
plus
cold operating costs = for example, the costs for refuse collection, (cold) water, staircase lighting, street cleaning and property tax.
Heating and hot water costs are taken into account separately.
Your benefits officer will explain to you how to proceed in case of unreasonable rent costs.
The "" Office for Housing and Migration of the state capital will advise you on all questions concerning housing in Munich.
If you are threatened with homelessness, we will look for a solution with you at
Sozialbürgerhaus.
Moving
If you want to move, your case worker must check whether the move is necessary and the costs of the new flat are reasonable before signing the tenancy agreement.
The following evidence and documents are required for the check:
Written justification of the reason for the move (if necessary, appropriate evidence proving an important reason).
Unsigned tenancy agreement or an offer of a flat showing all costs related to renting the flat (for example basic rent, ancillary costs and heating costs, deposit).
An important reason exists, for example, if:
the move remedies a threatened or existing homelessness;
the move ends or avoids the need for assistance;
the move is necessary in order to take up or continue employment subject to social security contributions at a greater distance (commute to work, depending on working hours, more than 2-2.5 hours total travel time).
Attention: If you rent a flat without the Job Centre's consent, you may suffer financial disadvantages.

question: What documents are required to apply for a driving license in Munich?
context:
Car driving
Car driving
Earning your driving licence
You are not allowed to drive a car without a driving licence.
To earn your driving licence, you must attend a certain number of practical and theoretical lessons and then pass both a practical and a theoretical test.
To apply for your driving licence at the Führerscheinstelle (Driving Licence Authority) and take the test, you need a valid identification document ([foreign] identity card, passport or residence permit), as well as a place of residence in Munich.
You must also be at least 17 (accompanied driving) or 18 years old.
The theoretical test can also be taken in English;
for the practical test, you must at least be able to follow the instructions given by the driving instructor and examiner in German.
You can even take driving lessons before submitting your application: the application is required only for taking the tests, as the Driving Licence Authority sends the corresponding examination order to Germany’s official certification body – the “TÜV”.
If you have questions about training and taking a test, find out more from a driving school.
Having a foreign driving licence converted
If you have a foreign driving licence, you can drive with it in for up to six months after you first register in Germany.
If your driving licence is not in Latin letters, you need an international driving licence right from the start.
After six months, you need to have certain types of driving licences converted.
This is not necessary if you posses a permanent driving licence from an EU or EEA country (Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway) without classes C, C1, C1E, CE, D, D1, D1E and DE.
Driving without a valid driving licence is a criminal offence.

question: How can I benefit from this law as a specialist?
context:

What is the Skilled Immigration Act?
Skilled workers can immigrate to Germany more easily.
This applies to specialists with
vocational training lasting at least two years or
University degree.
The Skilled Immigration Act lays down the rules.

Criteria for specialists
In principle, the following three criteria are considered:

With the EU Blue Card, skilled workers with a recognized qualification can come to Germany.
2) Experience
People with professional experience are allowed to come to Germany.
This applies to people who...
have acquired a recognized professional qualification abroad and
have at least 2 years of professional experience.
A salary threshold applies to these people.
This means that you must earn more money than the specified minimum amount.
Persons without a professional qualification recognized abroad must have their professional qualification recognized in Germany.
3) Potential
People without a concrete job offer can also work in Germany.
The opportunity card was introduced for them.
It is based on a points system.
These criteria are taken into account:
Qualification
German and English language skills
Professional experience
Reference to Germany
Age
Potential of spouses and partners
An important innovation for asylum seekers
Are you an asylum seeker?
And you were born before 29.
Then you can apply for a residence permit as a skilled worker.
You don't have to leave the country for this.
And you don't have to go through a visa procedure.
You have to withdraw your application for asylum.

a corresponding recognized qualification
a job offer or an existing employment relationship

question: How many votes does each voter have in the migration council election?
context:
How you can choose
How you can choose
In this election, you decide who gets a place on the Migration Advisory Council.
You have 40 votes.
The nominations (= lists) with the candidates for the migration council election are finalized at the end of January.
Ballot paper
On the ballot paper, all election proposals are sorted by initial letters from A to Z.
Each list has a number, a password and numbered candidates.
Each person's name, nationality and profession are listed.
Here you will find
all election proposals (lists) and one
Sample ballot.
You can also use a
Online trial ballot, test how the distribution of votes works.
Distribute votes
You have 40 votes.
If you distribute more votes, the ballot paper is invalid.
Here are four examples of how you can distribute the votes:
(1) Distribute votes freely
You can distribute your votes freely to the candidates on the entire ballot paper.
You tick all the people you want to vote for, regardless of which list they are on.
This is known as variegation.
You can also give special support to individuals and give them not just one vote, but two, but a maximum of three votes.
You can check the name multiple times.
Or you can write the number of votes (1, 2 or 3) in the box next to the name.
This is known as accumulation.
Please make sure that no one receives more than three votes from you.
(2) Select list
You can also select a complete list.
You only need to check the list once at the top of the password.
Your votes will then go to the candidates on this list in turn until all 40 votes have been distributed.
People who are listed three times get three votes.
People who are listed there twice receive two votes.
(3) Select list - with changes
If you select an entire list, you can still change something according to your wishes.
For example, you can delete one or more names from the list.
These people then do not get a vote.
You can also give special support to people on the list by giving them two or three votes.
(4) Select list and distribute additional votes freely
A mixed form is also possible: you can vote for a list (with or without changes) and also distribute votes freely.
This means that you can also tick people on other lists on the ballot paper and give them up to three votes.
The counting then proceeds as follows: On your ballot paper, all the votes you have given to individual persons are added up first.
What then of your
40 votes left will go to the list you ticked.
This means that all remaining votes go in turn to the persons on this list.
So no voice is lost.
All examples can also be found in the
Information sheet "How to vote".
Use the
Online sample order form to try out.
Test your vote.

question: On what legal basis are refugees recognized?
context:
Forms of protection in the asylum procedure
Forms of protection in the asylum procedure
If you apply for asylum, you are applying for protection in Germany and will not be deported.
The law provides for various forms of protection.
They correspond to different forms of persecution in the country of origin.
In an asylum procedure, it is checked which form of protection can be granted to you based on your individual situation.
Below you will find a brief overview of the various forms of protection.
You will find more detailed information in German, English, Turkish, Russian, French and Arabic under the links provided.
Eligibility for asylum
According to Art.
16 A of the Basic Law (Grundgesetz - GG) of the Federal Republic of Germany grants asylum to politically persecuted persons.
This protection status can be granted to persons who, due to
their ethnicity
their nationality
their political convictions
their basic religious decisions or
their membership of a particular social group (for example, on the basis of sexual orientation)
will be exposed to state persecution and serious human rights violations in their country of origin if they were to return.
Learn more
Refugee protection
According to the Geneva Refugee Convention, people are considered refugees if they are affected by state or non-state persecution for one of the following reasons and are outside their country of origin:
Ethnicity
Religion
Nationality
political conviction
Belonging to a certain social group (for example due to sexual orientation)
Legal basis: § 3 para.
Asylum Act (AsylG)
Learn more
Subsidiary protection
People who are at risk of serious harm in their country of origin and who cannot claim protection in their country of origin are eligible for subsidiary protection.
The threat can come from both governmental and non-governmental sources.
These include:
Death penalty
Torture
inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment
serious individual threat to the life or integrity of a civilian as a result of indiscriminate violence in an international or internal armed conflict
Legal basis: § 4 para.
1A sylG
Learn more
National ban on deportation
A person seeking protection may not be deported if
repatriation constitutes a violation of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (ECHR) or
there is a considerable concrete danger to life, limb or freedom in the country of destination.
Legal basis: § 60 para.
5 AufenthG, § 60 para.
7 Residence Act

You will learn the theory at vocational school one or two days a week.
You will learn practical work in a company three to four days a week.
The apprenticeship lasts two to three and a half years, depending on the profession.
You receive a salary.
How much you earn varies depending on the industry, company and year of training.
There are around 330 professions that can be learned in dual training.

question: What is TBE and how can I avoid it?
context:
Further STIKO vaccination recommendations
1. tBE (tick-borne encephalitis)
TBE is transmitted via tick bites.
Possible consequences of the disease are inflammation of the brain, the meninges and the spinal cord.
Bavaria, Baden-Württemberg and southern parts of Hesse, Thuringia and Saxony in particular are considered risk areas in Germany.
Vaccination against TBE is recommended by the STIKO in these areas in particular.
All children can be vaccinated against TBE from their 1st birthday.
2. flu (influenza)
Influenza is as contagious as a normal cold (flu-like infection).
Transmission in kindergartens and schools usually occurs from child to child.
Or about objects.
Children with pre-existing conditions are particularly affected.
They can lead to complications such as pneumonia.
The recommendation for an annual flu vaccination is therefore only aimed at children with a higher risk of complications.
You can find further information on the pre-existing conditions concerned here.
3. HPV (human papillomavirus)
Papillomaviruses can cause cancer in the long term.
Vaccination can therefore reduce the risk of cancer of the cervix, anus, penis and throat.
Vaccination before the first sexual contact offers the best protection.
Both vaccinations are recommended between the ages of 9 and 14.
4. meningococci
Meningococci are bacteria that can cause bacterial meningitis or blood poisoning (sepsis).
Children under the age of 5 and adolescents in particular are among the risk groups.
Vaccination against meningococcal type C is recommended at the age of 12 months.
There is currently no general recommendation for vaccinations against other types (B and ACWY).
The bacteria are transmitted via the so-called
Droplet infection.
This means, for example, coughing, sneezing or kissing.
5. pneumococci
Pneumococcus is the most common pathogen causing serious bacterial infections.
They can cause meningitis, pneumonia or middle ear infections.
They are particularly dangerous for babies and small children.
Three vaccinations against pneumococci are recommended.
These should be administered at the same time as the vaccination against tetanus, diphtheria and whooping cough.
6. rotaviruses
Rotaviruses are the most common cause of diarrhea and vomiting in children.
The pathogen is very contagious.
This is why almost all children contract the disease in the first five years - usually at the age of 2.
In infants in particular, a large loss of fluids and salt can lead to dangerous dehydration.
This may have to be
be treated in hospital.
Vaccination against rotaviruses is given two or three times, depending on the vaccine.
The first vaccination should be given between 6 weeks and 2 months of age.
The second vaccination at 3 months.
And the third, if necessary, at 4 months.
Vaccination against the coronavirus is currently only recommended for children aged 5 to 11 years with the "Comirnaty" vaccine from BioNTech/Pfizer.
Vaccinations can be given three to six weeks apart between the first and second vaccination.
The vaccination recommendation is primarily aimed at children who have an increased risk of a severe course due to a previous illness.
In addition, the recommendation also applies to children who are surrounded by people with a high risk of severe COVID-19 if they cannot be vaccinated themselves or the vaccination protection is not sufficient.
There is currently no recommendation for children without pre-existing illnesses or pre-existing illnesses of close contacts.
Nevertheless, it is possible to have your child vaccinated after consulting a doctor.
Further information on the pre-existing conditions concerned can be found at:
https://www.zusammengegencorona.de/impfen/kinder/corona-schutzimpfung-ab-5-jahren/

question: Who can do a voluntary internship?
context:
Important information about the internship
What is an internship?
An internship is a temporary position.
This means that interns work in a company or business for a limited period of time.
An internship can be done in almost any profession.
An internship is there to...
get to know a new profession,
get to know a working environment in practice,
and / or to deepen theoretical knowledge through practical (professional) experience.
What are the advantages of an internship?
An internship is very helpful before starting out in working life.
Interns get to know professions and fields of activity.
They can see which job is right for them.
Interns get to know companies and businesses.
They see if they want to work there.
Interns make contacts that can be helpful when entering working life.
The company gets to know the interns.
This may result in a job or apprenticeship after the internship.
For whom is an internship useful?
An internship can be useful for everyone.
When hiring new employees, for example, employers look at where the applicant has already completed internships.
Internships are particularly useful for:
Pupils,
Students,
People about to enter working life (to gain professional experience),
People who want to make a career change,
People who have been out of work for a long time.
The most important types of internships
Compulsory internship
Student internship: Students often have to do an internship at school.
The student internship often only lasts one to two weeks.
The aim is to familiarize pupils with working life and give them an initial career orientation.
Internship during studies: In order to complete your degree, you often have to do an internship.
The procedure and duration are regulated by the study regulations.
The compulsory internships provide initial work experience.
Voluntary internship
Anyone can do a voluntary internship - pupils, students or adults.
The duration is determined together with the company or business.
Payment
Interns sometimes receive money during their internship.
But not always.
This depends on several factors.
For example, the type of internship, the duration or even the sector.
Interns are entitled to payment if
the internship lasts longer than three months
and is voluntary.
This regulation does not apply to compulsory internships during studies.
The rule also does not apply to interns under the age of 18.
Ten tips for interns
Find out about the internship company before the internship (e.g.
B. on the Internet).
Be polite, punctual and reliable.
Show interest and motivation.
Ask if you want to know something or if something is unclear.
Address problems directly.
Stay friendly.
Accept criticism and learn from it.
Private is private: for example, avoid making private phone calls or constantly looking at your cell phone.
Dress appropriately.
Make new contacts.
These contacts can be helpful when looking for a job later on.
Apply for an internship certificate.
The internship certificate can be helpful later when looking for a job.

question: What is German Pension Insurance and what benefits does it offer?
context:
Pension
For many people, the question arises: What happens if I can no longer work in old age?
Germany has the social security system of the German Pension Insurance (DRV) for this purpose.
The German pension insurance website offers a lot of information and can answer some questions about pensions
German Pension Insurance
In principle, the pension is funded by contributions from employment subject to compulsory insurance.
As a rule, half of the contribution is paid by the employer and the other half by the employee.
If you are now in a position to claim a pension, you must apply for one.
The pension is not paid automatically.
You must submit an application at least 3 months before you plan to retire.
This makes the transition from employment to retirement easier.
You can find the nearest pension insurance advice center here.
There you can obtain more detailed information on your pension model and other benefits.
However, pension insurance not only pays a pension, but also provides other benefits.
This also includes rehabilitation measures, for example, in order to be able to work again.
It is important that the later pension benefit is not reduced as a result.
It can even increase if you remain fit for work for longer as a result of such a measure.

question: What are the steps for a longer stay in Germany with a D visa?
context:

Entry into Germany through a visa procedure
If you enter with a D visa for a longer stay in Germany, you must be aware of the following when you arrive:
The first thing you must do is register in your chosen town/city of residence.
German law gives you a period of 14 days after your arrival to do this.
In München you register in the Bürgerbüros (Residents’ Office).
In order to register or re-register, you can go personally to the Bürgerbüro (Residents’ Office) or have a person authorised by you bring the registration form, filled in and signed.
In both cases you need an appointment which you can arrange
online.
After you have successfully registered you will receive a registration certificate (Meldebescheinigung).
In the second step you apply for a residence permit:
The national visa (category D) was issued to you to enter Germany.
It is not issued for the planned duration of your stay however.
That’s why you need a residence permit.
You have to apply for the residence permit at the»» Ausländerbehörde (Immigration Office).
It’s important that you apply for the residence permit while your visa is still valid.
The residence permit is temporary but can be extended.
Independently of the reason for your entry to Germany, the residence permit also regulates:
If you are allowed to work or not,
What work you are allowed to do and
If time limits apply for employment in Germany.
Extending a residence permit:
Please note that you should apply to extend your residence permit already six to eight weeks before it expires.
Independently of the purpose of your stay, there may be other things to take into account.
You will also receive this information at the »» Ausländerbehörde (Immigration Office).

question: What should I do if I fall ill during my internship?
context:
Rights and obligations during an internship
Internship contract
No internship contract is required.
But it's good to have an internship contract.
This is because the regulations for the internship are laid down there.
Working hours
Depending on age, there are different regulations on working hours during internships:
Under 15 years of age: Work is generally prohibited.
This does not apply to internships for school pupils, for example.
Adolescents aged 13 and over may also carry out light activities (e.g.
e.g. tutoring, delivering newspapers).
Young people under the age of 15 are under special protection: they may work a maximum of 7 hours per day and a maximum of 35 hours per week.
Between the ages of 15 and 18: Young people of this age may work a maximum of 8 hours per day and a maximum of 40 hours per week.
Over 18 years: The regular working time of 8 hours per day should apply.
However, regular means that there may be exceptions.
If there is a lot to do, interns are allowed to work more than 8 hours.
A maximum of 10 hours may be worked per day.
Breaks
People on internships may and must also take breaks.
Age also plays a role in the break times:
Under 18 years of age: If you work between 4.5 and 6 hours, you must take a 30-minute break.
For more than 6 hours even 60 minutes.
Over 18 years: If you work for more than 6 hours, you must take a 30-minute break.
For working hours of more than 9 hours, even 45 minutes.
Duty of confidentiality
Interns learn a lot about the company during their internship.
Much of the information is confidential.
This means that interns are not allowed to pass on this information.
This is called "confidentiality".
For example:
One person is doing an internship in a doctor's surgery.
She learns a lot about the patients there.
For example, the names and illnesses of the patients.
She must not disclose this information to anyone.
Illness
In the event of illness, the intern must inform the internship company immediately.
Interns often need a medical certificate from a doctor.
It is best to ask the internship company whether a certificate is required.
Vacation
There is no entitlement to vacation during a mandatory internship.
It is possible to take vacation during a voluntary internship.

question: What requirements must be met for the residence permit in Germany to be terminated?
context:
Taxes and social security contributions
Taxes and social security contributions
Every employee pays part of their salary in taxes and social security contributions.
If you are self-employed, you must also pay taxes.
Income tax
Income tax contributes to the financing of federal, state and local government expenditure.
Taxpayers' money is used to build roads and schools, for example, or to finance social benefits.
If you are employed, you will receive the net amount of your salary from your employer, i.e. your taxes have already been deducted.
If you are self-employed, you are responsible for paying tax on your income.
Tax identification number
All employees receive a "tax identification number" at the start of their employment.
This tax ID is an 11-digit number and is used for income tax purposes.
It is valid for a lifetime.
Children born in Germany receive a letter with their personal tax ID within three months of birth, which is also required, for example, to apply for child benefit.
If you work in Germany, you will need the number again and again, for example for your employer.
If you do not know the number, you can ask for it in person at the registration office or in writing at the Federal Tax Office.
Tax return
In your annual tax return, you can claim various expenses from the tax office as tax-reducing.
This may result in either repayments in your favor or additional payments to the tax office.
Many people are required to submit a tax return, so it is best to ask the tax office whether this applies to you.
If you need help with your tax return, it is best to contact your local income tax association.
If you have further questions, the tax office can also help you.
Social security contributions
Social security contributions are the social security contributions that employees have to pay from their gross monthly salary in addition to taxes - this is mandatory by law and is automatically calculated by the employer.
Part of the social insurance is also paid by the employer.
Social security contributions finance the German social system.
If people cannot find work or are no longer able to work, the most basic living expenses can be secured in this way.
Ultimately, social security contributions serve the personal security of each and every individual - for example, if you become unemployed and have previously paid into unemployment insurance for a certain period of time, you are entitled to unemployment benefit I. Your monthly contribution to pension insurance also entitles you to a state pension in old age.
Social security contributions are made up of contributions for:
Pension insurance
Unemployment insurance
Health insurance
Long-term care insurance
The amount depends on the individual income.
The contributions are automatically deducted from your gross salary.
Exceptions for foreign employees apply, for example, if they have been posted to Germany by a foreign company, are employed or self-employed in several countries or are affected by other exemptions.
One of the requirements for a permanent residence permit is that you have paid pension insurance contributions for at least 60 months.
This also applies to self-employed persons.
There are also exceptions to this rule.
Social security number
German Pension Insurance will automatically send you your social security number by post when you take up your first job in Germany.
If you lose your number, you can ask to be notified again:
Telephone of the German Pension Insurance:

question: What rights are laid down in the Basic Law?
context:
Basic Law and human rights
The Basic Law
In every country there are rules that everyone has to abide by.
The most important law for Germany is the Basic Law.
It is a collection of 146 articles.
Each article stands for a law, i.e. a rule.
These rules determine how we live together in Germany.
Fundamental rights protect the freedom of each individual.
They are laid down in Articles 1 to 19 of the Basic Law (catalog of fundamental rights).
Here you will find the Basic Law in various languages.
Universal Declaration of Human Rights
Human rights are important rights that always apply to all people around the world.
Human rights are rights that every person has by virtue of being human.
They protect the dignity of every human being and are equally due to all human beings without distinction of any kind, such as skin color, gender, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, wealth, birth or other status.
There are 30 rights.
The most important are:
All people are worth the same.
Everyone is allowed to have their own opinion.
Right to peace and security.
The rules for living together in Germany are derived from these fundamental rights.
The State Office for Political Education of North Rhine-Westphalia has published the brochure "Demokratie für mich" (Democracy for me), in which these rules are clearly presented.
These rules and examples of what is and is not permitted in Germany are presented here under each keyword.

The Dublin procedure determines which country is responsible for carrying out your asylum procedure.
As a rule, it is the country in which you were registered for the first time.

It may be that Germany is not responsible for carrying out your asylum procedure.

Women and men have the same rights in Germany.
This is enshrined in Article 3 of the Basic Law.
Women can learn German, go to the doctor, learn a profession and look for a job.
You do not need permission from your husband or other family members.
Women can marry whoever they want and also separate or divorce if the relationship is not working or if the partner is violent.

When couples separate, the children can live with the mother, with the father or partly with the mother and partly with the father.
If the parents cannot agree on where the children should live, the court decides what is best for the children.
Despite equal rights, women are sometimes disadvantaged at work, in everyday life or in the family.

question: How can I apply for a work permit?

Not everyone is allowed to work in Germany.
An important criterion is your citizenship or residence permit.
Unrestricted access to the labor market
The following persons have unrestricted access to the German labor market:
Nationals of an EU country
Nationals of the European Economic Area (EEA)
Persons with Swiss nationality
These persons do not require a special permit for employment in Germany.
Groups of persons with special regulations
There are special regulations for certain groups.
For example for:
Specialists
Highly qualified
Holders of the EU Blue Card
Researchers
Self-employed persons
Jobseekers
Employees who come to Germany as part of transfers within their company
Persons with a residence permit
Citizens of a third country require a permit for permanent residence in Germany.
This is called a "residence permit".
The residence permit also includes access to the labor market.
Labor market access for refugees
Refugees with a residence permit
Recognized refugees with a residence permit are allowed to work.
Access to the labor market is normally unrestricted for them.

In AnkER facilities

Then you are not allowed to work for nine months.
After nine months, you are entitled to a work permit if
you come from a safe country of origin or

You can obtain a work permit from the Office for Immigration and Integration.

question: What happens if the Munich Administrative Court reaches a different decision in the legal proceedings than the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF)?
context:
6. legal action
Legal action
If you do not agree with the negative decision on your asylum application by the BAMF, you can appeal against this decision.
You are the "plaintiff" or the "claimant", the BAMF is the "defendant".
The Munich Administrative Court is reviewing the decision of the Federal Office in a lawsuit.
If the court comes to a different decision, it will oblige the Federal Office to grant you protection.
You will then receive a residence permit.
If, on the other hand, it confirms the negative decision, the claim is dismissed.
The obligation to leave the country remains in force.
You can also take legal action against a positive decision, for example if you do not agree with the form of protection granted (exception: granting of refugee status).
In any case, it is recommended that you seek advice and representation from a specialist lawyer for asylum and residence law.

After the personal interview, the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees checks all descriptions, information and evidence.
It is checked whether one of the four forms of protection exists on the basis of the Asylum Act:
Eligibility for asylum
Refugee protection
subsidiary protection
Ban on deportation
The asylum application will only be rejected if none of these forms of protection can be recognized.
The decision will be justified in writing and sent as a "notification" to
the applicant, or
to persons who have been authorized in these proceedings (lawyers).
the responsible foreigners authority.
The decision is negative
If your asylum application is rejected, you will receive a negative decision and a deportation warning.
Deportation threat means: You will be asked to leave the Federal Republic of Germany by a certain date.
If you do not leave the country by this date, you may be forcibly deported.
There are two different types of rejection:
simple refusal: you must leave the country within 30 days.
Rejection as "manifestly unfounded": In this case, the deadline for leaving the country is only one week.
Contestation
If you do not agree with the rejection, you can take legal action against the decision in both cases.
This must be done very quickly after receiving the decision.
Therefore, go immediately to the integration and refugee counseling service in your accommodation.
You will receive support there.
You should always seek advice and representation from a specialist lawyer for asylum and residence law if you wish to take legal action.
You will be informed of all deadlines and legal options in the written notification: This information is referred to as "information on legal remedies".

question: Where can I find support for my asylum procedure?
context:
General information on the procedure
Are you registered in Germany and living in shared accommodation?
What happens next?
Here you will find a series of multilingual explanatory videos on the subject of asylum procedures on the following topics:
Course of the asylum procedure
How do I prepare for the hearing?
What is an asylum decision and how does the appeal process work
The BAMF has compiled a lot of information for you here.
Here you will find a movie that explains the procedure.
The next steps are explained here:
1. personal application for asylum
You apply for asylum at the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF).
Important: You can only submit your application in person, you cannot send it by post.
You will receive the appointment and the responsible BAMF office with your proof of arrival.
If you have not been given an appointment, ask your social worker.
2. first interview appointment (asylum application)
A few days before your 1st appointment (asylum application, 1st interview appointment) or your 2nd appointment (interview, 2nd interview appointment), approach your social worker in the accommodation with your documents.
If you have your first interview at the BAMF, please remember to bring enough food with you.
There may be longer waiting times.
As long as you are in the asylum procedure, you have a residence permit.
3. personal interview
The 2nd interview date is the actual hearing.
The BAMF will decide on your asylum application.
It will then send you a notification (Bescheid).
Show the notification to your social worker.
They will explain to you what the BAMF has decided and what steps you can take.

question: Under what circumstances are interns entitled to payment?
context:
Important information about the internship
What is an internship?
An internship is a temporary position.
This means that interns work in a company or business for a limited period of time.
An internship can be done in almost any profession.
An internship is there to...
get to know a new profession,
get to know a working environment in practice,
and / or to deepen theoretical knowledge through practical (professional) experience.
What are the advantages of an internship?
An internship is very helpful before starting out in working life.
Interns get to know professions and fields of activity.
They can see which job is right for them.
Interns get to know companies and businesses.
They see if they want to work there.
Interns make contacts that can be helpful when entering working life.
The company gets to know the interns.
This may result in a job or apprenticeship after the internship.
For whom is an internship useful?
An internship can be useful for everyone.
When hiring new employees, for example, employers look at where the applicant has already completed internships.
Internships are particularly useful for:
Pupils,
Students,
People about to enter working life (to gain professional experience),
People who want to make a career change,
People who have been out of work for a long time.
The most important types of internships
Compulsory internship
Student internship: Students often have to do an internship at school.
The student internship often only lasts one to two weeks.
The aim is to familiarize pupils with working life and give them an initial career orientation.
Internship during studies: In order to complete your degree, you often have to do an internship.
The procedure and duration are regulated by the study regulations.
The compulsory internships provide initial work experience.
Voluntary internship
Anyone can do a voluntary internship - pupils, students or adults.
The duration is determined together with the company or business.
Payment
Interns sometimes receive money during their internship.
But not always.
This depends on several factors.
For example, the type of internship, the duration or even the sector.
Interns are entitled to payment if
the internship lasts longer than three months
and is voluntary.
This regulation does not apply to compulsory internships during studies.
The rule also does not apply to interns under the age of 18.
Ten tips for interns
Find out about the internship company before the internship (e.g.
B. on the Internet).
Be polite, punctual and reliable.
Show interest and motivation.
Ask if you want to know something or if something is unclear.
Address problems directly.
Stay friendly.
Accept criticism and learn from it.
Private is private: for example, avoid making private phone calls or constantly looking at your cell phone.
Dress appropriately.
Make new contacts.
These contacts can be helpful when looking for a job later on.
Apply for an internship certificate.
The internship certificate can be helpful later when looking for a job.

question: How can people without certificates prove their professional experience and skills?
context:
Recognition of foreign professional qualifications
In Germany, certificates play an important role for school, university or work.
They are proof of what you have already learned and achieved.
Certificates of school-leaving qualifications or professional qualifications are the decisive prerequisite for getting a job, a training place or a place at university.
If you have already obtained qualifications at school, in an apprenticeship or at university abroad, it often makes sense for the certificates to be recognized in Germany.
This means that they will check what you are qualified to do in Germany based on your certificates.
It may be that you no longer have your certificates.
In this case, you can try to prove your professional experience and skills through tests.
IQ recognition and qualification advice
Have you completed a vocational qualification abroad?
Have you already gained professional experience abroad?
Then the Recognition and Qualification Advisory Service is the right place for you to go.
The advice center will look at your documents.
She then compares your qualification with the German qualification.
For example, duration or content is compared.
Relevant professional experience is also taken into account.
At the end you will receive an assessment of whether you can get recognition or not.
Sometimes there are too big differences between foreign and German qualifications.
Because there are many factors to consider when recognizing professional qualifications, it is best to seek advice:
Door to door - Recognition and qualification advice
anerkennungsberatung@tuerantuer.de
www.migranet.org/angebote/ratsuchende/anerkennungsberatung
Telephone consultation hours: Monday and Thursday from 10 a.m. to 12 noon, Tuesday from 2 p.m. to 4 p.m.
Recognition grant
The recognition of foreign qualifications costs money.
The costs vary depending on the profession.
Some people can apply for a recognition grant.
This affects people who
live permanently in Germany,
have a low income and
are working below their professional qualification.
Get advice directly by e-mail or phone:
Research Institute for Vocational Education and Training (f-bb) gGmbH
anerkennungszuschuss@f-bb.de
Further detailed information
You can also find detailed information in eleven languages on the "Recognition in Germany" portal at www.anerkennung-in-deutschland.de.
The portal also offers a recognition app in German, English, Arabic, Dari, Farsi, Pashto and Tigrinya.

Many schools have school social workers.

School social workers advise and help with school and private problems, anger or other worries.

This means that they are not allowed to tell anyone about the problems.

Ask at your school.

If you have difficulties in some subjects at school and need additional support, you can register for tutoring.

Tutoring usually takes place in small groups or individually.

question: When do employers issue payslips?
context:

Payroll accounting
If you are employed, you will receive a payslip or payslip after the first month.
Some employers will continue to issue you with a monthly statement, others only if something is different in the month in question (e.g. Christmas bonus, increase in insurance contributions, etc.).
Mandatory information in the pay slip or payslip:
Name and address of the employer
Name, address, date of birth of the employee
Insurance number of the employer
Date of start of employment
Tax class and tax identification number
Billing period
Gross salary (salary without deductions - gross tax amount and gross social security amount)
Type and amount of supplements or allowances
Type and amount of deductions
Net amount (after all deductions)
The net amount is usually the amount paid out.
Exception: In the case of advances, loans from the company or salary garnishments (if you have debts), further amounts are deducted from the net amount.

question: What are house rules?
context:

House rules
The cohabitation of many or more people in one house requires mutual consideration and tolerance.
The landlord can stipulate certain rules for the cohabitation of tenants in an apartment building.
These rules are then laid down in the house rules.
The most important contents of house rules are
Quiet times/noise
Waste disposal
Use of the common areas
Ventilate

Waste separation
Waste must be disposed of in the garbage cans provided.
There are different garbage cans for plastic, paper and cardboard, for fruit and vegetable waste (organic waste) and for other waste.
Please keep to waste separation, as a large part of the waste is reused and it is an important part of environmental protection.
What belongs in which garbage can?

Saving energy through ventilation and correct heating
Make sure that you ventilate regularly.
This means that you open the window fully for five minutes at least three times a day.
It is also important that you heat correctly.

question: Who ensures that children attend school regularly?
context:

Compulsory schooling
School attendance is compulsory in Germany: all children between the ages of 6 and 15 have to go to school.

Vocational school attendance is compulsory from the age of 18 if attendance at a general school is not continued.
Compulsory vocational schooling does not apply if the school was completed with the Abitur or Fachabitur.

If a child is ill, parents must call the school before 08:00 in the morning.

If the child attends a public primary or secondary school, it must go to the school that is responsible for its place of residence - a Sprengelschule.

question: What means of transportation can I use in Augsburg and the surrounding area?
context:
Public transportation
There is a good network of public transportation in Augsburg and the surrounding area, such as buses and streetcars.
The Augsburger Verkehrs- und Tarifverbund (AVV) is responsible for this network.
You can find all the important information on the AVV website at www.avv-augsburg.de.
For app users, both AVV (app: AVV.mobil) and Stadtwerke Augsburg (app: swa FahrInfo) offer free apps for download.
You need a ticket to travel by bus or streetcar.
Checks are often carried out on buses and streetcars.
If you do not have a ticket, you will have to pay a fine.
The second time, you will be reported to the police and fined much more.
So make sure you always have a valid ticket with you!
Fare zones and price levels
The area in which the AVV operates is divided into zones.
The price of the tickets depends on the number of zones traveled through.
The more zones you pass through, the more expensive your ticket will be.
Each zone corresponds to a price level.
Each zone is only counted once.
For example, if you travel through zones 20, 10 and 20 again, you need a ticket for price level 2 or
2 stripes on the stripe card.
However, the outward and return journeys count as two separate journeys.
The Augsburg city area includes fare zones 10 and 20.
The district of Augsburg comprises zones 30 - 70.
You can find the fare zone map here.
The timetables with the fare zones are also displayed at the stops.
Note: Your ticket is also valid if you change trains.
The most important tickets
Detailed information on all tickets and current prices can be found here.
Germany ticket
For 49 euros a month, you can use all means of public transportation and travel throughout Germany.
The Deutschlandticket is a subscription.
This means that it is automatically renewed every month.
But you can cancel it every month.
Always by 10.
of each month (for example: 10.
March) for the following month.
You can order your Germany ticket here.
It is then played on the smartphone.
You will need the "myAVV" app for this.
You can find the app in your smartphone's Apple or Google store.
Discount ticket for students, trainees, civil servants or volunteers
In Bavaria, these groups of people can get a discounted Deutschlandticket.
The discount ticket costs 29 euros.
It is also valid nationwide.
This ticket is valid for trainees from 01.
The person's place of education or residence must be in Bavaria.
To apply, you need a certificate of eligibility from your training center / educational institution.
You can apply for the discount ticket here.
Stripe card
9 strips for flexible use (one strip per zone)
Valid for 3 hours (no return and round trips)
No take-away options (one strip per person and zone)
You can find more information about the strip card here
One-way tickets
Once from A to B
Valid for 1 hour (no return and round trips)
No take-away options
4 Stops after boarding buses or streetcars, even across zone boundaries
Change possible
You can find more information about one-way tickets here.
Day ticket
Any number of journeys on the selected day
For adults aged 15 and over
For one person or groups (each additional person costs an extra charge)
Up to 4 children under the age of 14 can travel free of charge.
Valid Monday to Friday from 9:00 a.m., Saturday, Sundays and public holidays all day;
valid until closing time (i.e. until the last bus or streetcar leaves).
Please note: The names of the passengers must be handwritten on the day ticket!
You can find more information about the day ticket here.
365-euro AVV ticket for school pupils, trainees, interns and FSJ volunteers
The 365-euro AVV ticket is available for school pupils, trainees, interns and young people doing a voluntary social year.
For €1 a day, you can travel as often as you like on streetcars, buses and trains throughout the AVV network area - around the clock!
You can pay for the ticket in installments or all at once.
You can find all the information here.
Monthly pass for pupils
Pupils do not have to pay for the bus and streetcar themselves.
You can submit an application.
The cost of the monthly pass will then be covered.
For this, the journey to school for pupils in grades 1 to 4 must be more than 2 km.
For children and young people from the 5th grade onwards, the journey to school must be longer than 3 km.
Further information and download of the applications: www.landkreis-augsburg.de
Call and collect cab (AST), on-call bus
The call-and-collect cab (AST for short) and the on-call bus operate when there are no regular bus or train connections.
For example, a cab will pick you up from the station or a bus stop and take you to the door of your desired destination.
The journey request must be made by telephone at least 30 minutes before departure.
The regular AVV prices apply.
You can find more information here.
AktiVVO - minibus as required
The minibus runs on demand without fixed stops and without a fixed timetable.
Trips in the minibus can be booked by telephone or in the "AktiVVO" app.
Within a short time, passengers can get on and off at one of the AktiVVo stops or at the AVV regional bus stops.
The fare for the AktiVVo corresponds to the regular AVV fares.
The AktiVVO minibus commutes in these regions:
Holzwinkel and Altenmünster, Roth and Zusam valleys
Bobingen, Königsbrunn and Schwabmünchen
The AktiVVO is only on the road in these regions.
He's not going to Augsburg either.
It does not travel to any locations outside these regions.
Augsburg City Zone
In the city of Augsburg, you can use the bus and streetcar free of charge at a total of 9 stations around Königsplatz and the main railway station.
The free stops are one stop in each direction from Königsplatz and Moritzplatz.
You can find more information here.
At night
With the night bus you are also mobile at night (0.30 to 4 am).
The night buses run from Thursday to Sunday and on public holidays.
Passengers require a special night ticket (also available on the buses).
Regional trains run on some routes.
The regular AVV fare applies here.

question: What is not allowed in Germany?
context:
Religious freedom
Religious freedom
Religion and faith are private matters in Germany.
The state does not dictate to anyone whether and in which God he or she should believe.
State and religion are separate.
This means, for example:
All people are free to practise and choose their religion and beliefs.
All people have the freedom to be non-religious and to say so.
Anyone who does not believe in God is allowed to say so publicly.
Members of different religions and faiths are allowed to marry each other.
Marriage only counts as a legally valid marriage if it is concluded before the registry office.
Marriages entered into exclusively within the framework of a religion are not legally binding in Germany.
This is not permitted in Germany, for example:
Putting religious rules or traditions above applicable laws, for example being married to several women at the same time or slaughtering an animal without special permission.
Boys may only be circumcised if this does not endanger their welfare.
Many people in Germany today are committed to dialog between religions.
The aim is the peaceful coexistence of religious people, people of faith and people of no religion.
The state is committed to ideological neutrality.
As long as the practice of a religion does not endanger democracy or the separation of state and religion, it is protected.

question: Under what conditions can a settlement permit be issued?
context:
Permanent residence
Permanent residence
Settlement permit according to § 9 Residence Act
With a settlement permit, you can live and work in Germany without any time or place restrictions.
Prerequisites (selection):
Legal residence in Germany for at least five years (previous periods of study and training are credited at 50 percent)
valid residence permit that was not issued for a temporary purpose (studies) or for humanitarian reasons
Proof of secure livelihood and living space
Proof of sufficient pension provision (at least 60 months of compulsory or voluntary contributions to statutory pension insurance in Germany)
sufficient German language skills and basic knowledge of the legal and social system and living conditions in Germany - usually demonstrated by
successful participation in an integration course
or
through certificates and proof of study relating to vocational training completed in Germany or other language certificates
Further documents may be required in individual cases.
Further information on the requirements can be found here.
Permanent residence - EU
The EU permanent residence permit is an unlimited residence title and offers the same rights as the settlement permit.
With the permit, you can live and work in Germany without any time or place restrictions.
In addition, you can also live, work or study in the countries of the European Union (except Ireland, Denmark, Great Britain) (special regulations apply for individual countries).
Information on the requirements can be found here.
Whether a settlement permit or an EU permanent residence permit is more favorable for you depends on your individual circumstances.

question: Why is an internship helpful before starting work?
context:
Important information about the internship
What is an internship?
An internship is a temporary position.
This means that interns work in a company or business for a limited period of time.
An internship can be done in almost any profession.
An internship is there to...
get to know a new profession,
get to know a working environment in practice,
and / or to deepen theoretical knowledge through practical (professional) experience.
What are the advantages of an internship?
An internship is very helpful before starting out in working life.
Interns get to know professions and fields of activity.
They can see which job is right for them.
Interns get to know companies and businesses.
They see if they want to work there.
Interns make contacts that can be helpful when entering working life.
The company gets to know the interns.
This may result in a job or apprenticeship after the internship.
For whom is an internship useful?
An internship can be useful for everyone.
When hiring new employees, for example, employers look at where the applicant has already completed internships.
Internships are particularly useful for:
Pupils,
Students,
People about to enter working life (to gain professional experience),
People who want to make a career change,
People who have been out of work for a long time.
The most important types of internships
Compulsory internship
Student internship: Students often have to do an internship at school.
The student internship often only lasts one to two weeks.
The aim is to familiarize pupils with working life and give them an initial career orientation.
Internship during studies: In order to complete your degree, you often have to do an internship.
The procedure and duration are regulated by the study regulations.
The compulsory internships provide initial work experience.
Voluntary internship
Anyone can do a voluntary internship - pupils, students or adults.
The duration is determined together with the company or business.
Payment
Interns sometimes receive money during their internship.
But not always.
This depends on several factors.
For example, the type of internship, the duration or even the sector.
Interns are entitled to payment if
the internship lasts longer than three months
and is voluntary.
This regulation does not apply to compulsory internships during studies.
The rule also does not apply to interns under the age of 18.
Ten tips for interns
Find out about the internship company before the internship (e.g.
B. on the Internet).
Be polite, punctual and reliable.
Show interest and motivation.
Ask if you want to know something or if something is unclear.
Address problems directly.
Stay friendly.
Accept criticism and learn from it.
Private is private: for example, avoid making private phone calls or constantly looking at your cell phone.
Dress appropriately.
Make new contacts.
These contacts can be helpful when looking for a job later on.
Apply for an internship certificate.
The internship certificate can be helpful later when looking for a job.

The use of anti-constitutional symbols and calls to overthrow democracy.
Insulting expressions of opinion that disparage other people.
Defamation or slander against other people.
To incite hatred and violence.

After the personal interview, the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees checks all descriptions, information and evidence.

Deportation threat means: You will be asked to leave the Federal Republic of Germany by a certain date.

simple refusal: you must leave the country within 30 days.
Rejection as "manifestly unfounded": In this case, the deadline for leaving the country is only one week.
